info.name: Open Plantbook API Public
info.description:
Documentation for Open Plantbook API.

[https://open.plantbook.io](https://open.plantbook.io)

This is free service but it requires registration and API credentials. The credentials need to be generated from Web UI under API keys.

Project page:

[https://plantbook.io](https://plantbook.io)

item.name: Sensor-data (experimental)

body.raw:
{
  "custom_id": "abelia chinensis on window",
  "pid": "abelia chinensis",
  
  "location_name": "Sydney",
  "location_region": "New South Wales",
  "location_country": "Australia",
  "location_lon": "43.11",
  "location_lat": "-15.88",
  "location_by_IP": "true"
}

request.description:
## Register Plant Instance

Create User's Plant-Instance for the plant's sensors data uploading. The single entry uniquely identifies a plant instance and the set of bound sensors. 
If either \<pid\> or \<custom_id\> is changed then new Plant-Instance is created.

It includes the plant's location which helps to understand environment where the plant grows so it is highly encouraged to provide this information. 

There are 3 options in the order of priorities. Only 1 option needs to be specified:
1. Coordinates longitude and latitude (preferable). Does not have to be precise location but just approximate coordinates. 
1. Location Name and Country. This is less preferable option as it is prone to typos and parsing error. E.g. Name: "Sydney, New South Wales" Country: "Australia".
1. Location is taken from IP address (default behaviour) The IP address is not stored but just used to identify approximate location.

Location is only registered on Plant-Instance creation. It is not updated when registering the same plant (same \<pid\> and \<custom_id\>) with different location.

API client is expected to register Instance-Plant once and they store its ID. They reuse ID to upload sensor data. Although, client can make this call with the same \<pid\> and \<custom_id\> and the end-point return ID of the existing instance.

### Mandatory attributes:

```
- "pid" - Plant ID is unique plant identifier.
- "custom_id" - This is a plant identified set by a user. It helps to differentiate plant instances when for example a user has 2 instances of the same plant (the same "pid")
```

### Optional attributes:

```
- "location_lon" - location longitude coordinate where plant is located.
- "location_lat" - location latitude coordinate where plant is located.
- "location_by_IP" - Default is "true" if not specified. "false" - disables the location by IP detection.
- "location_name" - Location name in well known to the location format. API will make it is best to parse and derive the specific location.
- "location_region" - Location region within country.
- "location_country" - Location country.
```

### Returns:

Response includes ID in UUID format. This is a unique Plant-Instance identifier that is used as JTS "node" to upload sensor data.
```
201 - New Plant-Instance has been created and location registered.
200 - Plant-Instance (identified by <pid> and <custom_id>) already exists. No action.
400 - Validation error E.g.: Plant's PID found neither in user-plants nor in public-plants or if a mandatory attribute has not been provided. 
```

body.raw:
{
  "custom_id": "abelia chinensis on window",
  "pid": "abelia chinensis",
  
  "location_name": "Sydney",
  "location_region": "New South Wales",
  "location_country": "Australia",
  "location_lon": "43.11",
  "location_lat": "-15.88",
  "location_by_IP": "true"
}

query.description: Instructs API to only validate JTS payload but does not commit values to the database.

request.description:
# Sensor data upload

Upload plants sensor data using JSON-time-series (JTS) protocol.
Formal specification: https://docs.eagle.io/en/latest/reference/historic/jts.html

To bind sensor data to a particular plant, Plant-Instance ID is used as <id> which needs to be registered first with "Plant-Instance Register" API call first.

The endpoint supports "dry_run=true" query parameter. It instructs API to only validate JTS payload and does not commit values to the database. Please use it when developing/testing integration with mock or test data. It helps to keep DB in order and only store valid sensors data.

Plantbook API specific JTS Document specification:

### Header (required)
|Attribute|Example|Description|
|---|---|---|
docType|jts|Required. Must be ‘jts’
version|1.0|Required. Version ‘1.0’ supported
header| |Required. Object describing document data
data| |Required. Array of historic records in chronological order

### Header Columns (required)
Below is only supported and defaults values of optional attributes if they are not specified

|Column Attribute|Default|Description|
|---|---|---|
|id| |(Required) Plant-Instance ID (UUID)
name| |(Required) Name of sensor measurement. Supported values: ['temperature', "conductivity", "humidity", "moisture", "light"] See note on units below.|
|dataType||(Required) Data type of associated node. Supported values: [NUMBER] 
renderType|VALUE|Rendering of ‘v’ attribute in records. Supported values: [VALUE]
format|0.#|Format of the value. Supported values: [0.#]

Note: if column attribute is omitted the it will be set to default value.

**Units of Measurement.** The units are the same as in DB. Currently unit conversion is not support so all the units needs to be converted prior uploading to supported ones.

|Measurement|Unit|Description|
|---|---|---|
conductivity|µS/cm|
humidity|%|
moisture|%|
light|lux|
temperature|Degrees C|

### Data (required)

|Record Attribute|Example|Description|
|---|---|---|
|ts|2018-08-16T02:00:00.000+11:00|(Required) ISO8601 timestamp of data point(s) **IMPORTANT!** Send timestamp with information about original TimeZone. Do not convert to UTC. Otherwise, TZ will be lost and it will be not impossible to determine day/night time for the plant.
|f| |(Required) Object containing data for 1 or more columns (using column index as key)
|v|10.4|(Required) Value of column for the corresponding record timestamp Data type should match dataType option in header

## Returns:

```
200 - Successfully uploaded.
400 - Malformed request. See detail field for specifics about a problem. E.g.: if validation or parsing failed. 
```
Note: JSON-schema validation returns pretty comprehensive error description which include lots of escaped text so it is recommended to unescape it for a better readability using for example https://onlinetexttools.com/unescape-text

item.description:
Plants' sensors data upload API calls.

**NOTE:** This set of API calls is set as experimental at this point in time. This means that it may be changed in near future as this is feature is still in development. Once the development is completed the experimental flag will be removed.

item.name: 1. Authentication
OAuth2 Client-Credentials OAuth Grant - Get token

formdata.description: Client ID from "API keys" in open.plantbook.io UI
Client Secret from "API keys" in open.plantbook.io UI

request.description:
Request OAuth2 access token to make API calls.  
This is first step to work with the API. The token valid for "expires_in" seconds (value in the token) hence there is no need to request new token within this period.

formdata.description: Client ID from "API keys" in open.plantbook.io UI
Client Secret from "API keys" in open.plantbook.io UI

item.description:
API supports two types of authentication:
* OAuth2 Client Credentials 
* API-key

**1) "OAuth2 Client Credentials grant".**

**NOTE:** This method is supported across all endpoints.

The sequence:
- Generate ClientID and ClientSecret (client credentials) in UI.
- Using above Client's credentials, get OAuth2 Bearer token from API's token endpoint. The token is valid for limited time. So you need to request new token once it is expired (or prior any request for simplicity).
- Call API with the issued "Bearer" token. It is done with HTTP header "Authorization" and value of header consist key word "Bearer" and then token value.
```
Authorization: Bearer NjJeh5Ew9arEiJKLU9zJELukbxebew
```

More information about OAuth "Client Credentials" grant: https://docs.pingidentity.com/bundle/developer/page/ixj1601508083821.html

**2) "API-key" authentication.**

**NOTE** API-key is only supported for "plant/search" and "plant/detail" endpoints.

This is simplified authentication based on permanent token which is generated when you enable "API-key" authentication in UI. This token will never expired and can be used infinite number of times. 
The sequence:
- Enable "Token" authentication and take copy of permanent API-key token.
- Call API with the API-key token.
It is done with HTTP header "Authorization". The difference with OAuth authentication is that the KEY word is "Token"(!) and then token value.
```
Authorization: Token 228d654c09c6a17006d5421eba175a9a15dca07e
```

query.description: number of entries in the result
True - search and return only user-plants, False - search and return only public-plants, absent - combined search user and public - return deduplicated result

request.description:
# Search plants by text
Search any occurrences of text in "display_pid" and "alias" fields.

# Query parameters:
* 'alias' - search string. This parameter is mandatory except when userplant=true. In this case endpoint returns all user's user-plants.

* 'userplant' - user/public plants search selector:
    true - search and return only user-plants,
    false - search and return only public-plants,
if omitted - combined search across user and public plants - returns deduplicated result

* Pagination parameters: limit=X offset=Y  [see here][ref].
[ref]: https://www.django-rest-framework.org/api-guide/pagination/#limitoffsetpagination

Deduplication algorithm works as:
1. Search public-plants with a search string.
2. Search user-plants with a search string.
3. Exclude user-plants from public-plants list.
4. Also exclude public-plants which exist in user-plants but does not match search string.
5. Combine user-plants and public-plants in one list.

response.name: Plant Search with OAuth Bearer token

header.description: Token value received from /api/v1/token/ endpoint with keyword "Bearer"

query.description: number of entries in the result
True - search and return only user-plants, False - search and return only public-plants, absent - combined search user and public - return deduplicated result

header.description: API-key token value from UI with keyword "Token"

query.description: number of entries in the result
True - search and return only user-plants, False - search and return only public-plants, absent - combined search user and public - return deduplicated result

request.description:
## Get plant details
Retrieve plant details using "pid" (Plant ID) as: /api/v1/plant/detail/pid/

E.g.:
/api/v1/plant/detail/acer buergerianum/

How it works:
* Endpoint searches user-plants first. If found then returns the user plant and add a field {"user_plant": True}
* If no user plants found then it searches public plants. If found the return public plant without adding extra field "user_plant".


* Trialing slash is required!
* Result will include {"user_plant": True} attribute if the plant is from user-plants.

# Create new user plant or modify public plant.

Accept JSON payload with parameters. See example.

## Mandatory attributes:
    <display_pid> - Scientific name of the plant. Based on this attribute <pid> (Plant ID) attribute will be automatically generated by lowering case of this attribute.
    E.g: <display_pid>="Tomato Red" will result in <pid>="tomato red". See postman example for details.

All omitted non-mandatory attributes will have null value.


## Returns:
    201 - Successfully created.
    409 - Plant already exists either in user DB or main DB.
    400 - Malformed request e.g. if a mandatory attribute is not provided.

# Delete plant

Delete plant from user-plants. Public-plants cannot be removed.

## Mandatory attributes:
    "pid" - Plant ID - unique plant identifier. Case SENSITIVE!
    
## Return:
    204 - Successfully deleted.
    404 - Plant does not exist in user DB.
    400 - Malformed request e.g. if a mandatory attribute is not provided.    

## Known issue:
It does not handle omitted mandatory attribute correctly and always return 404 Not Found even if "pid" is absent.

# Update plant

Method updates either user-plant or public-plant using JSON payload.
User-plant is attempted to update first. If user-plant not found then API searches 'pid' in public-plants. If found in public-plants then the public plant will be cloned and saved as user-plant with requested changes.

Endpoint supports PATCH (partial update - updates only provided attributes), PUT is not supported

## Mandatory attributes:

```
- "pid" - Plant ID is unique plant identifier. Case SENSITIVE!
- at least 1 field with plant's attribute is required. This is to avoid dull duplicates.
```

## Returns:

```
200 - Successfully updated.
404 - Plant exist neither in user-plants nor in public-plants
400 - Malformed request e.g. if a mandatory attribute is not provided. 

```
